text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's Austrian newspapers:
DER STANDARD

- Finance Minister Rudolf Edlinger said even a referendum could not stop Austria introducing the European Union's single currency because this has been already decided by a "yes" vote in a referendum on membership of the European Union.

- Social Democrat party whip Peter Kostelka wants the government to decide on Austria joining NATO after the next general elections. A governmental report on the country's future security policy does not have to contain a recommendation on NATO.

- The Social Democrat party plans an alliance with Christian voters, party general secretary Andreas Rudas said. The move follows announcement by the far-right Freedom Party that it will target the religious vote.
- Electronic retailer Koeck plans to restructure by setting up a financial holding to oversee its three operating subsidiaries.
- Tennis: Gilbert Schaller saved Austria's hopes of rejoining the Davis Cup world group by beating Andreas Hirszon of Croatia in the fifth match in Graz in southern Austria.
DIE PRESSE
- Edlinger expects eight to eleven countries to join European Economic and Monetary Union.

- 800 million schillings in contributions will be taken away from public accident insurance company AUVA to finance the ailing pension system. Meanwhile AUVA is insisting it must be paid for the treatment of visiting patients.
KURIER
- Social Minister Eleonore Hostasch is considering reforming Austria's pension system to make the financing of future pensions possible.
- Former Chancellor Franz Vranitzky wants the Social Democrats to have their own candidate for the next presidential elections in 1998.
- Austria has submitted its work programme for the country's European Union presidency in the second half of 1998.

- Federal rail OeBB chief Helmut Draxler wants the government to contribute more to a new tunnel through the Semmering mountain in eastern Austria because private financing is proving to be too expensive.
- Austrians are using more and more credit cards. Currently there are 1.2 million credit cards in the country and the number is growing by ten to 15 percent a year.
SALZBURGER NACHRICHTEN
- Austria plans to start the harmonization of taxes during its presidency of the European Union.
- Austria's trade balance will remain negative as structural problems have not yet been removed.
- Austrians donated 3.3 billion schillings in 1996. Children and handicapped received the majority of contributions.
